;周三，一名在乌克兰首都法院引爆爆炸装置的男子死亡内政部长伊霍尔·克利缅科 (Ihor Klymenko) 援引“初步信息”称，他将自己封锁在大楼的一部分内。

;

;特种快速反应安全部队的两名成员在试图将该男子控制在大楼内时受伤。舍甫琴基夫斯基法院位于首都中心。事件期间听到两声巨响。

;

;Klymenko 在现场向记者介绍情况时表示，该男子“可能……死于爆炸装置”。

;

;在 Telegram 消息中写道他在应用程序中写道：“根据初步信息，他引爆了自己。”

;

;Klymenko 确认嫌疑人为伊霍尔·胡梅纽克 (Ihor Humenyuk)，并表示他一直作为与四名乌克兰人死亡有关的嫌疑人参加听证会。 2015 年国民警卫队人员。

;

;听证会结束后，他说该男子首先将自己锁在浴室里，并向两名警卫投掷爆炸装置。

;

;被警察阻止离开大楼克雷门科说，他向空中开枪，然后将自己关进另一个房间。

;

;他拒绝与官员谈判，并向两名受伤的警察扔了另一个装置。

;

;自杀式爆炸造成人员伤亡喀布尔教育中心的 19 名男子（主要是女孩）

;

;Klymenko 表示，该男子在这场争吵中被杀。调查正在进行中，以确定他如何在法庭上持有爆炸物。

;

;下午 5 点刚过，接到爆炸报告后，警方赶到了现场，并看到救护车进出大楼。 .

;

;视频片段显示，至少一名受害者被担架抬出。

;

;部长在声明中没有提及与俄罗斯的任何联系，俄罗斯开始了全面的制裁。 2022 年 2 月入侵乌克兰。

;历史在阿富汗重演。在美国领导的联军介入清除基地组织几十年后，在此过程中塔利班的恐怖组织再次在该国蓬勃发展，并造成了致命的后果。

;

;这是在联合国阿富汗援助团联阿援助团上周发布了一份报告，披露了自 2021 年 8 月 15 日塔利班接管以来在恐怖袭击中丧生的平民人数。

;

;据联阿援助团称，共有 1,095 名平民死亡，其中包括 287 名儿童，另有 2,679 人受伤从 2021 年塔利班接管到今年 5 月 30 日之间。大多数伤亡是由市场、清真寺和学校等人口稠密地区的简易爆炸装置 (IED) 造成的。

;

;袭击已成为阿富汗日常生活的一部分。去年 9 月，一名自杀式炸弹袭击者在喀布尔的一所教育中心造成至少 35 人死亡。几周前，首都一座拥挤的清真寺在晚间祈祷期间发生爆炸，造成 21 人死亡、33 人受伤。这些袭击让阿富汗人生活在恐惧之中。

;

;虽然平民伤亡率大幅下降，但2020 年记录的 8,820 起，反映了不断变化的安全动态。此前，阿富汗人在塔利班叛乱中或被前阿富汗国家安全部队或其西方盟友的部队杀害。现在，他们在喀布尔等城市中心遭到恐怖组织的袭击。

;

;联合国报告强调“不仅此类袭击造成持续的平民伤害，而且自八月以来自杀式袭击的致命性有所增加2021年12月15日，袭击次数减少，造成平民伤亡增加”。

;

;这是恐怖组织在阿富汗活动急剧增加的直接结果。数据表明，由于塔利班不作为或治理不善，这些团体得以逍遥法外。

;

;塔利班否认了这些指控。首席发言人扎比胡拉·穆贾希德声称，政府“完全控制局势，不会允许任何组织或实体破坏阿富汗稳定”。二月份，塔利班表示，其安全部队击毙了两名伊斯兰国主要指挥官，并以此作为其认真对待反恐的证据。

;

;但实际情况却并非如此。自塔利班掌权以来，两个恐怖组织尤其蓬勃发展。

;

;其中最著名且最致命的是伊斯兰国呼罗珊组织 (Isis-K)，它是在伊拉克和叙利亚活动的逊尼派极端组织“伊斯兰国”的一个分支。 。 2015 年出现的“伊斯兰国”-K 组织因 2021 年美国混乱撤军期间在喀布尔机场外发生的爆炸事件而臭名昭著。那次袭击造成约 170 名阿富汗平民和 13 名美国士兵死亡。

;

;自塔利班卷土重来以来，“伊斯兰国”组织-K在阿富汗获得了更大的立足点，并继续针对哈扎拉人、什叶派和苏菲派少数民族。自 2021 年 8 月以来，它已声称对七起伤亡惨重的恐怖袭击负责，估计造成 970 人死伤。

;

;虽然塔利班也是逊尼派运动，但它认为“伊斯兰国”组织是一个与伊斯兰国不同的敌人。思想。 Isis-K利用恐怖袭击控制阿富汗部分地区，并向塔利班施加压力。

;

;然而，塔利班与基地组织的关系有所不同。去年，联合国报告称，两者之间的关系“仍然密切”，并且“基地组织在塔利班的领导下拥有避风港，行动自由也有所增加”。

;

;这种密切关系在以下方面显而易见：去年8月，塔利班经历了一个尴尬的时刻，当时美国无人机袭击了基地组织领导人艾曼·扎瓦希里（Ayman al-Zawahiri），据报道，扎瓦希里住在塔利班助手的家中。

;

;塔利班甚至任命了塔利班高级官员- 基地组织领导人卡里·巴亚尔（Qari Baryal）首先担任喀布尔省省长，然后担任卡比萨省省长。巴亚尔被指控在阿富汗各地组织和实施爆炸事件。

;

;显然，塔利班要么没有能力，要么不愿意打击恐怖主义。国际社会似乎也同意这一点。

;

;塔利班的顽固态度意味着阿富汗仍然是令中国、俄罗斯头疼的问题

;

;6 月，联合国负责反恐事务的副秘书长弗拉基米尔·沃龙科夫 (Vladimir Voronkov) 表示，塔利班“无法或不愿意遏制恐怖主义威胁”。

;

;美国总统拜登和印度总理莫迪最近还发表联合声明，呼吁塔利班遵守联合国安理会第2593号决议，该决议要求阿富汗领土永远不应该被用来庇护和训练恐怖分子或资助恐怖袭击。

;

;作为阿富汗的主要投资者，中国也提出了批评。去年，喀布尔一家深受中国公民欢迎的酒店遭到“伊斯兰国”组织轰炸，中国对此表示震惊。五名中国人在袭击中受伤，中国政府随后要求所有公民离开该国。

;

;阿富汗安全局势的恶化是北京方面的主要担忧。中国不希望恐怖主义扩大并蔓延到东突厥斯坦伊斯兰运动活跃的西部省份。

;

;Isis-K 还威胁到中国在阿富汗的商业利益。去年 9 月，该组织在其《呼罗珊之声》杂志上警告北京不要投资阿富汗的自然资源，这可能引发冲突。

;

;出于这些原因，中国正在向塔利班施压，要求其应对

;

;5月，外交部长秦刚利用三方论坛要求塔利班“认真对待邻国的安全关切，采取更有力的措施打击阿富汗境内的各类恐怖势力”。

;

; >;

;毕竟，拒绝驱逐基地组织及其领导人奥萨马·本·拉登导致塔利班在 2001 年被驱逐。虽然塔利班不太可能很快被推翻，但不解决这个问题可能会产生严重后果。

;苏格兰周三举行盛大游行，庆祝查尔斯国王和他的妻子卡米拉的加冕典礼充满盛况和庄严的教堂仪式，他被授予英国最古老的皇冠上的宝石“苏格兰荣誉勋章”。

;

;查尔斯和卡米拉于 5 月在伦敦威斯敏斯特教堂在约 100 名世界领导人面前加冕这是英国七十年来最盛大的庆典活动。

;

;这位 74 岁的老人据说对苏格兰有着深厚的感情，在伊丽莎白女王登基时继承了他的母亲，成为英国和其他 14 个王国的君主。 9 月去世。

;

;但是，为了承认英格兰和苏格兰在 1603 年王冠统一之前拥有不同君主这一历史事实，苏格兰在周三分别举行了庆祝活动，以预示他的加冕典礼。

;

;人群聚集在爱丁堡著名的皇家大道上，为代表苏格兰生活各个方面的约 100 人组成的人民游行队伍和由数百名军人以及军用管乐队和鼓乐队组成的皇家游行队伍欢呼。;

;但是，在场的还有大约 100 名反君主主义者，他们发出嘘声并大声高呼：“不是我的国王。”

;

;在该市圣吉尔斯大教堂举行的全国感恩节和奉献仪式上，查尔斯被授予苏格兰荣誉勋章 - 历史悠久的苏格兰皇冠宝石，在过去五个世纪中一直在皇家仪式中使用。

;

;其中包括苏格兰王冠，于 1540 年为苏格兰国王詹姆斯五世制作，曾用于1543 年加冕苏格兰玛丽女王，权杖据信是 1494 年教皇亚历山大六世授予詹姆斯四世的。

;

;查尔斯国王在美国总统的欧洲外交之旅中会见乔·拜登

;

;“通过这顶王冠的象征，我们宣誓我们的忠诚，委托您作为我们的国王统治，为所有人民服务，”汉密尔顿和布兰登公爵以及苏格兰最资深的贵族亚历山大·道格拉斯·汉密尔顿说道，当他向查尔斯赠送放在垫子上的王冠时。

;

;查尔斯回答道：“在接受这顶王冠时，我保证得到上帝的帮助。”他的长子和继承人威廉王子和查尔斯王子也参加了仪式。他的妻子凯特。命运之石是苏格兰民族的象征，于 13 世纪被带到英格兰，并于 1996 年返回苏格兰，也被移至大教堂举行仪式。

;

;从爱丁堡鸣响了 21 响礼炮城堡，在红箭特技飞行队进行飞行表演之前，游行队伍返回荷里路德宫。

;

;与加冕典礼本身一样，君主制的反对者也提出了抗议，民意调查显示该机构与英国其他地区相比，这种运动在苏格兰不太受欢迎。

;

;警方表示，他们逮捕了两名年龄分别为 20 岁和 21 岁的妇女，据称她们试图翻越皇家大道上的人群安全屏障。

;

;苏格兰独立问题仍然是一个突出的政治问题，一些支持分裂的人也希望有一个民选国家元首。

;

;“爱丁堡这场毫无意义的虚荣游行将使苏格兰纳税人付出代价。数百万英镑，为了什么？这样查尔斯就可以再次成为一天的焦点，”反君主主义组织“共和”的首席执行官格雷厄姆·史密斯（Graham Smith）说，他于 5 月份在伦敦加冕典礼上被捕。

;未能通过集中分配系统进入心仪学校的香港学生可能会在当局将中一班级的“上门”名额数量减少一半后，他们很难在其他首选学校获得一席之地。

;

;香港资助中学议会周三对这一计划表示欢迎这是教育局的决定，因为上门安排产生了“抢椅子效应”，学生不断转学。

;

;学生在中学分两个阶段分配学位。第一批学生根据学业成绩、面试成绩等因素确定名额，其余学生需参加机考集中分配。

;

;第二阶段结果预计将于近期公布下周二。

;

;该局证实了《华盛顿邮报》早些时候的报道，表示学校只能使用每个中一班级为留级学生提供的两个名额之一来招收对分配学校不满意的未来学生.

;

;教育局经过深思熟虑和听取持份者意见后决定，由2023-24学年开始，中一每班只可使用一名重读生名额来收录非重读生”，该局在一封信中告诉学校。

;

;该局补充说，新政策确保这些名额将用于其最初的目的，即留级生。学校界普遍认为，减少上门学额可以在一定程度上防止学生转学的“抢椅子效应”，在学生人数下降的情况下威胁学校的生存。

;

;小六人数参与编配制度的学生人数由 2020-21 学年的 54,112 人减少至 2021-22 学年的 52,055 人，并进一步降至 2022-23 学年的 49,448 人。

;

;在公营及直资计划学校就读的小六学生人数为约 49,363。该数字预计将很快更新。

;

;香港家长寻求“上门”进入热门学校的名额“急剧下降”

;

;教育局表示，可自由支配名额的减少将将于2023-24年起试行三个学年，并警告称，将于9月校园清点工作中检查学校是否遵守新规定。

;

;“教育局将跟进资助中学理事会主席李宜英表示，她的组织欢迎这项政策，并称其为学生人数下降的“纾困措施” .

;

;她说：“这可以帮助稳定该行业，并减少学生人数减少带来的冲击。”

;

;李，同时也是九龙塘的中学校长指出去年希望进入自己选择的学校的学生的满意度为 83％，并表示鉴于创纪录的高数字，家长不必担心。

;

;学校仍然可以提供尚未入学的学校名额。她说，在集中分配给“上门学生”后进行注册。

;

;香港中学最新计划削减“上门”学额

;

;2021年和2022年，教育局呼吁中学只为复读生使用酌情学额，因为这才是初衷。

;

;根据官方统计，官立及资助中学有近1,600个中一班级。

;

;但校长们表示，新政策将留下 1,600 个可自由支配的名额供争夺，因为不受欢迎的学校不太可能收到学生的任何申请。

;6 月份官方制造业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 5 月份的 48.8 升至 49，但仍保持在低于月度增长与收缩的 50 分界线。

;野村分析师表示，官方制造业 PMI 的小幅反弹集中在生产方面，新订单分类指数也从 48.3 微升至 48.6

;

;但新出口订单分类指数跌至五个月低点 46.4，直接纳入整体制造业 PMI 计算的五个分类指数中的三个在 6 月份小幅下降。

;

;与此同时，财新/标普全球制造业 PMI 从 5 月份的 50.9 回落至 6 月份的 50.5，表明经济活动略有扩张。

;

;凯投宏观 (Capital Economics) 中国经济学家朱利安·埃文斯-普里查德 (Julian Evans-Pritchard) 和谢娜·岳 (Sheana Yue) 表示：“财新指数显示，有利于小型企业和靠近海岸的企业的有利因素正在减弱。”

;

;取官方和财新的平均值调查显示，产出部分下降，似乎反映出外国需求下行压力加大。

;

;虽然新订单部分基本保持不变，但出口订单部分进一步下降至五个月低点，表明出口再次下降。

;

;“总的来说，两者的平均值与上个月工厂活动的轻微恶化相符，”Evans-Pritchard 和 Yue 补充道。

;

;

;

;由于对现场服务的需求减弱，6 月份中国服务业的活动也放缓。

;

;衡量服务业和建筑业商业信心的官方非制造业 PMI部门，从 5 月的 54.5 降至 6 月的 53.2。

;

;在非制造业指标中，服务业分类指数从 5 月的 53.8 降至 6 月的 52.8，而建筑业分类指数则跌至六个月低点野村证券 (Nomura) 分析师指出，在为期三天的端午节期间，新冠疫情后旅游业和流动性的复苏似乎失去了动力，而建筑业也继续放缓，因为平均价格水泥等建筑材料跌至2017年以来新低。

;

;与此同时，财新/标普全球服务业PMI从5月的57.1回落至6月的53.9，跌至1月以来的最低值。

;

;“总的来说，两项调查都表明，在短暂的重新开放推动之后，服务业似乎正在进入新冠疫情后增长放缓的常态，”Evans-Pritchard 和 Yue 补充道。凯投宏观。

;

;

;

;PMI始终是中国经济实力的先行指标，而6月份的PMI显示经济动能依然疲弱。

;

;“最近的数据显示，全球经济正在放缓，这可能会给未来几个月的外部需求带来进一步的压力，”品点资产管理公司总裁兼首席经济学家张志伟表示。

;

;“另一方面考虑到去年的基数较低，政府今年 5% 的[经济]增长目标相当温和。

;

;“目前尚不清楚疲软的经济数据是否会促使政府推出激进的刺激措施很快。”

;

;中国将于7月中旬发布第二季度国内生产总值数据，今年前三个月，世界第二大经济体同比增长4.5% .

;

;李强总理表示，中国第二季度经济增长将快于第一季度，但由于去年基数较低，因此增速更有可能更高。

;

; >;

;全球投资银行已经下调了第二季度环比增长预测，从平均 4% 以上下调至 1% 左右或低于 1%。

;

;“PMI 调查显示， 6月份中国的重新开放复苏势头继续减弱。制造业的下行压力持续存在，”凯投宏观的埃文斯-普里查德和岳补充道。

;

;“财政支持的减弱给建筑活动带来了压力。就连今年早些时候的一个亮点——服务业增长，现在也已低于疫情前的水平。

;

;“如果有更大的政策支持，经济在今年剩余时间内仍应取得一些进展。 ，但收益可能不大。”

; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Monday was the hottest day ever recorded, Tuesday was even hotter as global temperatures continue to risehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3226689/monday-was-hottest-day-ever-recorded-tuesday-was-even-hotter-global-temperatures-continue-rise?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;The entire planet sweltered to the unofficial hottest day in human record-keeping July 3 and then blasted past that with an even hotter day on July 4, according to University of Maine scientists at the Climate Reanalyzer project.

;

;For two straight days, the global average temperature spiked into uncharted territory. After scientists talked about Monday's dramatic heat, Tuesday soared 0.17 degrees Celsius (0.31 degrees Fahrenheit) even hotter, which is a huge temperature jump in terms of global averages and records.

;

;The same University of Maine climate calculator – based on satellite data and computer simulations – forecasts a similar temperature for Wednesday that would be in record territory, with an Antarctica average that is a whopping 4.5 degrees Celsius (8.1 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than the 1979-2000 average.

;

;High temperature records were surpassed July 3 and 4 in Quebec and northwestern Canada and Peru. Cities across the US from Medford, Oregon to Tampa, Florida have been hovering at all-time highs, said Zack Taylor, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service. Beijing reported nine straight days last week when the temperature exceeded 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit).

;

;“The increasing heating of our planet caused by fossil fuel use is not unexpected, it was predicted already in the 19th century after all,” said climate scientist Stefan Rahmstorf at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Research in Germany. “But it is dangerous for us humans and for the ecosystems we depend on. We need to stop it fast.”

;

;The daily but preliminary and unofficial heat record comes after months of “truly unreal meteorology and climate stats for the year,” such as off-the-chart record warmth in the North Atlantic, record low sea ice in Antarctica and a rapidly strengthening El Nino, said University of Oklahoma meteorology professor Jason Furtado.

;

;Thailand's mass fish deaths caused by climate change, expert suspects

;

;This global record is not quite the type regularly used by gold-standard climate measurement entities like the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association. But it is an indication that climate change is reaching into uncharted territory. It legitimately captures global-scale heating and NOAA will take these figures into consideration when it does its official record calculations, said Deke Arndt, director of the National Center for Environmental Information, a division of NOAA.

;

;“In the climate assessment community, I don't think we'd assign the kind of gravitas to a single day observation as we would a month or a year,'' Arndt said. Scientists generally use much longer measurements – months, years, decades – to track the Earth's warming. In addition, this preliminary record for the hottest day is based on data that only goes back to 1979, the start of satellite record-keeping, whereas NOAA's data goes back to 1880.

;

;But Arndt added that we wouldn't be seeing anywhere near record-warm days unless we were in “a warm piece of what will likely be a very warm era” driven by greenhouse gas emissions and the onset of a “robust” El Nino. An El Nino is a temporary natural warming of parts of the central Pacific Ocean that changes weather worldwide and generally makes the planet hotter.

;

;Human-caused climate change is like an upwards escalator for global temperatures, and El Nino is like jumping up while standing on that escalator, Arndt said.

;

;On Tuesday, American independence day, Earth average temperature spiked at 17.18 degrees Celsius or 62.9 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the University of Maine's Climate Reanalyzer, a common tool often used by climate scientists for a good glimpse of the world's condition. Tuesday's temperature was nearly a full degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit) warmer than the 1979-2000 average, which is itself is warmer than the 20th and 19th century averages.

;

;On July 3, the reanalyzer had the temperature at 17.01 degrees Celsius (62.6 degrees Fahrenheit).

;

;The reanalyzer is based on a NOAA computer simulation intended for forecasts that use satellite data. It is not based on reported observations from the ground. So this unofficial record is effectively using a weather tool that is designed for forecasts, not record-keeping.

;

;The global daily average temperature for July 3 came in at 17.01 degrees Celsius or 62.6 degrees Fahrenheit. This average temperature may not seem that hot, but it's the first time in the 44 years of this data set that the temperature surpassed the 17-degree Celsius mark and then it went even higher.

;

;“A record like this is another piece of evidence for the now massively supported proposition that global warming is pushing us into a hotter future,” said Stanford University climate scientist Chris Field, who was not part of the calculations.

;

;Hotter global average temperatures translate into brutal conditions for people all over the world.

;

;In the US, heat advisories are in effect this week for more than 30 million people in places including portions of western Oregon, inland far northern California, central New Mexico, Texas, Florida and the coastal Carolinas, according to the National Weather Service Weather Prediction Center. Excessive heat warnings are continuing across southern Arizona and California, they said.

;

;When the heat spikes, humans suffer health effects.

;

;“Those hotter temperatures that happen when we get hotter than normal conditions? People aren't used to that. Their bodies aren't used to that,” said Erinanne Saffell, the Arizona state climatologist and an expert in extreme weather and climate events.

;

;Saffell added that the risk is already high for the young and old, who are vulnerable to heat even under normal conditions.

;

;“That's important to understand who might be at risk, making sure people are hydrated, they're staying cool, and they're not exerting themselves outside and taking care of those folks around you who might be at risk as well,” she said.

; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 China’s quiet strides in the climate change fight are an example to allhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3226442/chinas-quiet-strides-climate-change-fight-are-example-all?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.05 22:30;
;;

;A pristine area of rainforest the size of Switzerland was razed last year with untold loss of irreplaceable biodiversity. Enormous wildfires in Canada have unleashed vast quantities of carbon dioxide to exacerbate global warming while also choking residents across North America. Sea lions and dolphins are dying in unprecedented numbers off the coast of California, and storms, floods and famine of increasing regularity and seriousness are taking place worldwide.

;

;You would have to be bereft of your senses and lack any grip on reality not to appreciate, with all the available evidence, that something dangerous is happening to the world's climate and having seriously negative effects on all living things. It is accelerating and setting records – and not in the good way.

;

;Many governments are starting to get serious, with fine words being spoken and even some coordinated actions taken through bodies such as the United Nations' climate summits.

;

;At the same time, there is a popular uprising of sorts, with groups such as Just Stop Oil and Extinction Rebellion. People in countries across the world are organising to demand their political leaders take bolder actions on climate change.

;

;At the same time, the Covid-19 pandemic, the terrible, grinding war caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the global crisis in cost of living, inflation and other related problems are distracting us at the worst possible time. These things are taking our attention from the urgent actions we must all take to help address the fundamental and existential threat the planet is facing.

;

;People want action, but there is serious lag. The risks are rapidly increasing that it will all be too little, too late.

;

;The world needs bold leadership and exemplary initiatives to follow now, not tomorrow. We need practical examples of efforts to get ahead of the climate change tipping points rather than languishing far behind them.

;

;It seems to me that China can accept this mantle. As other countries debate, argue, shift blame and pontificate as the world burns, China has implemented a wide range of projects to tackle its own carbon footprint head-on. Its approach is multifaceted, technology-focused, scalable and being enacted at a steady, sustainable pace.

;

;A wave of actions is unfolding in China. One is the recent approval for a 2 megawatt liquid-fuelled thorium molten salt reactor (MSR) located in the desert city of Wuwei in Gansu province. This technology, whose potential has been known for decades, offers exciting prospects. It is cleaner and safer than its uranium-based equivalents. It also has more accessible and abundant fuel reserves and a more efficient power source.

;

;If it was not for the needs of the nuclear weapons programmes of the 1950s onwards, the world's nuclear power inventory could now be dominated by more environmentally friendly thorium salt nuclear installations.

;

;China is rich in thorium salt reserves. In the future, it could deploy significant numbers of molten salt reactors to take advantage of these resources. They could become part of the nation's multipronged solution towards eliminating any need to burn fossil fuels for power generation.

;

;India also has an active thorium salt reactor programme, and valuable collaboration between these important geopolitical players is possible.

;

;Another project of note is the commissioning of the hybrid solar-hydro Kela power plant in the Yalong River plateau in Sichuan province that can produce 2 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity annually, equal to the power consumption of 700,000 households for a year.

;

;Then there is the research in fusion power via facilities such as the Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak in Hefei, Anhui province, and China's international collaboration in the ITER fusion facility being built in France. The US$25 billion International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) is the world's biggest international fusion project, certainly its most ambitious.

;

;China's current deployment of solar power already provides more than 225 gigawatts of renewable energy, which is more than from the entire rest of the world combined. There is something to be said for centralised organs of power that can mandate and effect such enormously important projects on rapid timescales for the benefit of all.

;

;At the same time, China is working to reverse desertification through planting millions of trees. A 2021 report by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization states that China's forest cover has increased from 157 million hectares in 1990 to about 220 million hectares by 2020. Furthermore, as part of China's 14th five-year plan unveiled in March 2021, there is a target of increasing forest coverage to 24.1 per cent by 2025.

;

;Trees are a vital carbon sink. They help regulate our climate, filter the water we drink, provide vital habitats for other plants, insects and other wildlife and, of course, emit oxygen. This does not replace the loss of virgin rainforest mentioned earlier, but it is nevertheless a good thing.

;

;Finally, China is undertaking a rapid introduction of electric cars. It has overtaken Japan as the world's largest car exporter and leads this particular sector and research into vital battery and solar panel technologies. This means the prospect of less particulate pollution in Chinese cities, improved air quality and reduced need for petrol.

;

;So without much fanfare and with serious deliberate intent, China is making important and increasing strides both nationally and internationally in addressing the climate change problem. The rest of the world should take note and replicate such bold and profound moves.

;Jiang Mingtao's ginseng farm in the US state of Wisconsin has halved production since China began levying tariffs of up to 40 per cent on the coveted plant known for its health benefits five years ago.

;

;Beijing made the move against the root, that Chinese consumers prize to boost immunity and ease certain chronic diseases, in 2018 as former US president Donald Trump kicked off his trade war with China.

;

;With wholesaling to China no longer profitable, China-born Jiang has tried switching to carrots and corn, but neither crop brings in the kind of money made from ginseng.

;

;The former doctor, who had always wanted to run a business, operates a farm in Marathon County, a tract of the Midwestern state Wisconsin and the source of most China-bound ginseng thanks to its cool climate and unique topsoil composition.

;

;“Not much else to grow,” said Jiang, who first moved to Canada 14 years ago for his PhD before attending medical college in Wisconsin.

;

;“I am hanging in with the government's payroll protection plan and a small business loan from the government.”

;

;Jiang might consider himself among the fortunate of Marathon County, which has a population of 138,000, as around 100 farmers have quit growing ginseng altogether, said Katie Rosenberg, mayor of the county seat of Wausau.

;

;She said the normally US$20 million crop makes up a third of the agricultural county's economy, with dairy and beef making up the remainder.

;

;“It's so typical to blast-off on China in a way that's not helpful,” Rosenberg said. “It hurts us to have a bad relationship with the world's second-largest economy.”

;

;Tariffs have fallen back to 32 per cent, but they are still higher than the pre-2018 level of just 7.5 per cent.

;

;Beijing has long called for the removal of the US punitive tariffs and this issue could be raised when US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen begins a four-day visit to China from Thursday.

;

;Making shipments more expensive, the Chinese consulate in Chicago must also notarise ginseng exports from Marathon County, with more documentation rigours following at entry ports in China, Rosenberg added.

;

;Ginseng exporters are also required to use standardised shipping containers, she said, creating a burden for farmers with smaller shipments.

;

;“It seems like there's a lot of paperwork that's bogging down this process,” she said.

;

;Jiang has to spend an extra US$8,000 on packing materials for ginseng shipped via the port city of Shenzhen to end markets in China.

;

;Neither the domestic ginseng market, even the ginseng beer that a local merchant has started making, nor interest in other ginseng-loving Asian countries can offset sales to China before the trade war, Rosenberg added.

;

;

;Wisconsin ginseng, mostly from Marathon County, had made a mark for its quality in the same vein as Bordeaux wine from France and Wagyu beef from Japan.

;

;Rosenberg, Jiang and other growers in the county have targeted Capitol Hill in Washington to press lawmakers to resolve the trade dispute that has sparked tit-for-tat tariff increases covering US$550 billion worth of bilateral trade.

;

;Rosenberg also spoke to the Office of the US Trade Representative and asked the Wisconsin state government for trade-war relief.

;

;But Rosenberg, and the farmers who help her advocacy work, have found that distrust of China runs so deep in Washington that legislators will not push for any changes.

;

;“We need to have diplomacy, and that's how we'll succeed in our global economic landscape, and that's not popular,” said Rosenberg, who advocates tariff cuts.

;

;“I want these conversations to keep happening.”

;

;Ginseng consumers in China link the root to traditional Chinese medicine, and many see American ginseng as a means to “expel heat”, according to a member of staff at the Crcare medicine shop in the busy Hong Kong shopping district of Causeway Bay.

;

;The Eu Yan Sang traditional Chinese medicine shop, also in Causeway Bay, sells boxes of processed Wisconsin ginseng for HK$69 (US$8.8).

;

;A saleswoman at the shop said the Wisconsin variety is sought after for its “strong but not bitter” flavour.

;

;

;American ginseng, though, is becoming harder to source due to world climate fluctuations, she added.

;

;Trump initiated the trade war because of what he saw as “unfair” Chinese trade practices, such as limited market access, intellectual property theft and forced technology transfers.

;

;Tariffs raised by China pushed US agricultural exports down by 53 per cent in value to US$9 billion in 2018 compared to 2017, the Congressional Research Service said.

;

;The offices of lawmakers contacted about US-China trade ties did not return calls or emails, including Senator Marco Rubio and congressmen Brad Sherman and Mike Gallagher. The Wisconsin-based Ginseng Growers Association of America trade group also declined to comment.

;

;

;In Marathon County, Will Hsu's 50-year-old, family-owned ginseng farm has cut staff by 40 per cent and has reduced the acreage planted by almost the same degree.

;

;The Chinese tariffs and higher production costs in Marathon County have allowed Canadian and Chinese ginseng growers to take market share, he said.

;

;Hsu said he has “talked to every US senator and representative who will listen to me”, but has been told that “we're not talking to China”.

;

;Hsu's operation has switched its focus on “premium consumers” in China, who pay around US$200 to US$400 per kilogram.

;

;Taiwan and Vietnamese markets may also eventually expand, said Hsu, who is of Taiwanese ancestry. Normal prices were around half the current level before the trade dispute, he added.

;

;Hsu's farm stays in business now by drying ginseng for other farmers, selling supplies and repairing equipment.

;

;Jiang plans to keep his ginseng crop, and hopes for an eventual tariff reduction.

;

;He plans to keep asking legislators for trade-war relief, but in the meantime, he has made his first shipments to South Korea and Japan.

;

;Ginseng enjoys a similar reputation in both countries for its health benefits, but both lack the market size of China.

;

;“We are looking for other avenues of distribution for our products,” he added.
